PROJECTS UNDER THE NEAREST SCHOOL - THE BEST
asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Education, Higher Education and Vocational Education:

(a) Will she inform this House the - (i) number of projects that were launched in government schools in the Central Province under the project named "The Nearest School - the Best School"; (ii) number of those, out of the aforesaid projects, that have been completed and have not been completed, separately; and (iii) measures that will be taken to expeditiously complete the projects that have not been completed yet? (b) If not, why?
() ( ) ( () - , ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Madhura Senevirathna - Deputy Minister of Education and Higher Education) , ,
TRANSPORT OF LIMESTONE FROM PALAVIYA TO ARUWAIKADU: AGREEMENT WITH DEPARTMENT OF
asked the Minister of Transport, Highways, Ports and Civil Aviation:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) whether locomotives, coaches and other equipment belonging to Sri Lanka Railways have been leased out for transporting limestone from Palaviya in Puttalam to the Aruwaikadu Limestone Quarry; (ii) if so, the name of the company to which above-mentioned equipment have been leased out; (iii) the income that has been earned by Sri Lanka Railways by leasing out the said equipment from the year 2015 up to now, separately in respect of each year; and (iv) whether action will be taken to review the above-mentioned lease agreement in relation to the current requirements?
( ) ( - , , ) (The Hon. Bimal Rathnayake - Minister of Transport, Highways, Ports and Civil Aviation and Leader of the House of Parliament) ,

: ACCESS ROAD TO KUKULE-GANGA POWER STATION:

(a) Will he inform this House the - (i) time period when acquiring lands for the Kukuleganga Power Station Construction Project was commenced; and (ii) extent of land that was acquired for the project concerned?

(b) Will he also inform this House - (i) whether he is aware of the access road to the power station concerned; (ii) the points at which the access road concerned starts and ends; (iii) whether he is aware that the bus bearing route number 437 plies along the access road and the road itself has transformed into a public transport road; (iv) the length of the part of that road belonging to the Kukuleganga Power Station; (v) whether he is aware that due to lack of proper maintenance, nearly half of the part concerned of that road is in an unsafe condition; (vi) whether steps will be taken to maintain that part of the road properly; and (vii) if not, whether the road concerned will be vested in the Road Development Authority?

(i) whether he accepts that an excellent service is provided by the "Suwa Seriya" ambulance service; and
(ii) if so, the measures that will be taken to further strengthen and expand the said ambulance service?

DEPLOYMENT OF NEW BUSES ON EXISTING ROUTE
asked the Minister of Transport, Highways, Ports and Civil Aviation:

(i) the bus owners holding route permits issued by the National Transport Commission and who sold their unroadworthy buses during the period when import of vehicles into Sri Lanka had been suspended had to wait until the import of buses recommenced in order to purchase a new bus;
(ii) during the above-mentioned period, the bus owners concerned had surrendered their route permits to the said Commission;

(iii) when new buses are put into operation after the import of buses has recommenced, the Provincial Road Passenger Transport Authority charges an outstanding fee for issuing chart sheets even for the period during which the buses were not in operation;
(iv) it was not possible for the bus owners to put new buses into operation, as they were unable to purchase buses during the period when import of buses were suspended; and
(v) it is therefore unfair to charge an outstanding fee for the period during which buses were not operated when issuing chart sheets for the new buses?
(b) If so, will he inform this House of the solution that will be given in this regard?

NEW SHOPPING COMPLEX, MINUWANGODA: LEASE OF TRADE
() , ? asked the Minister of Public Administration, Provincial Councils and Local Government:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) whether he is aware that there is a shopping complex known as the New Shopping Complex belonging to the Minuwangoda Urban Council situated in Minuwangoda Town; (ii) the number of trade stalls (shops) available in the said shopping complex; and (iii) separately, the name and address of each person who has obtained the said stalls on lease basis and the monthly or annual rent charged on each of the stalls concerned?

(b) Will he also inform this House - (i) whether the persons who have obtained the stalls in the above-mentioned shopping complex on lease basis have the legal right to sell, sub-lease, or transfer the ownership of the said stalls to another person; (ii) whether the original lessees who have obtained the said stalls by entering into lease agreements with the Minuwangoda Urban Council are the ones currently conducting business in the stalls; (iii) if not, whether he will submit a list of names of the persons who are currently conducting business activities in the said stalls; and
(iv) whether legal action has been taken against those persons?
(c) If not, why? ( ) .... ( ) ( () .... - , ) (The Hon. (Prof.) A.H.M.H. Abayarathna - Minister of Public Administration, Provincial Councils and Local Government) ,
asked the Minister of Plantation and Community Infrastructure:

(a) Will he inform this House - (i) the tea smallholders' contribution to the total tea production in Sri Lanka as a percentage; (ii) whether he accepts that the tea factories perform an important role during the production process from raw tea leaves to the finished good; (iii) the number of registered tea factories in Sri Lanka located in each district, separately; (iv) whether he accepts that the above-mentioned factories are actually located physically on the respective lands; (v) if so, whether the aforesaid fact has been ascertained through an on-site inspection; (vi) if not, the reasons for it; and (vii) whether any of the above-mentioned tea factories/ any factory has departed from producing finished tea for any reason?

RACIST, RELIGIOUS AND HATEFUL STATEMENTS MADE ON
) ( - () ) (The Hon. Ajith Agalakada on behalf of the Hon. (Dr.) Najith Indika) - (2):
asked the Minister of Health and Mass Media:
(a) Will he inform this House- (i) whether he is aware that propaganda in the

nature of defaming the Government has been carried out on social media regarding the commemoration of the dead persons of the Northern Province of Sri Lanka; (ii) the legal provisions currently in force
against the making of organized racist, religious and hateful statements on social media; (iii) the Acts most frequently used in the past,
out of those referred to above; (iv) whether a course of action has been

developed to prevent the defamation caused to the Government by the failure to promptly give the correct factual explanation of the Government after misinformation has been disseminated by the media; and (v) the measures that will be taken to rectify
this situation and to avoid any recurrences of such in the future?

: RECIPROCAL RECOGNITION, REGISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT OF FOREIGN JUDGMENTS
ACT: ORDERS [ 1049] ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Harshana Nanayakkara, Attorney-at-Law - Minister of Justice and National Integration) , :

Let me continue in English, Hon. Speaker. Last Sunday, there was an article in a reputed Sunday newspaper. As you are aware, we, on a policy basis, did say that we will take steps to abolish the pension of Parliamentarians who had served just five years and also that we will attend to the Presidents Entitlements Act to take away the privileges which we thought was immoral for an ex-President to have. For that purpose, we have been working on the subject for a while. And, last Monday, I presented a Cabinet Paper for those two Acts -

the Presidents Entitlements Act and the Parliamentary Pensions Act - to be repealed with repeal Acts and that proposal was accepted by the Cabinet. So, accordingly, I am in the process of taking the next steps to bring in those two laws to repeal the Presidents Entitlements Act and the Parliamentary Pensions Act in the near future after the due course of procedure has been followed. But, what happened, Sir, is that a particular newspaper, after an RTI request, has obtained information of the Action Plan of the Ministry of Justice and National Integration and made a headline news that the Government has reversed its policy, but not in the words "Presidents Entitlements Act". So, that was a front-page news continued half way through. That particular news in that Sunday newspaper is partly true and partly, does not process the information they have. It is pointless being a journalist, if you are unable to process the information you have. Sir, this is what happened. There was an Action Plan. At the beginning of this year, the Presidential Secretariat informed us of 58 activities in the policy document and to prepare the subjects. Accordingly, we did prepare them, but there were certain subjects which were not within the purview of the Line Ministry. A couple of them were Subjects 17 and 18. Subject 17 in that Action Plan was to do with amending the parliamentary electoral system and Subject 18 was about abolishing the pensions and special privileges given to retired Presidents. Those two particular subjects were not within our Line Ministry. So, accordingly, we informed the Presidential Secretariat that those be deleted from our Action Plan because they technically belong elsewhere. That is, with the President. Then, a few days later, we got a reply from the Presidential Secretariat deleting those two proposals. Writing about the deletion of proposals from a Ministrys Action Plan equating it as a reversal of policy by a government is done either by someone who does not know how to process an information or someone who is trying to mislead the public. And, the public was misled because we spoke to many of our supporters and citizens, explaining this is what happened. So, what I am saying to those authors is this. Sir, I will fall short of calling it fake news; I will not call it fake news, but they were either unable to process the information they had to come out with the right news because they did not know the procedure or they had some other ulterior motives. But, either way, that is what happened. According to Article 44 of the Constitution, the President can assign any subject under him to any Minister. So, the fact that those subjects had not been in the programme does not mean that we were reversing them. But, that was the message the newspaper was giving either deliberatly or by accident, I do not know. If it was by accident, it is a serious problem because unlike social media and other YouTube platforms, traditional journalism must be more careful with the information they give out to the public, especially when the newspaper has a reputation.

Anyway, I will not find fault with that newspaper, but want to just remind them that getting the information is not enough; they must process their information properly and come out with the correct news, which, I believe, they failed to do. And, the fact that we have now passed it in the Cabinet should put that speculation to rest. So, Sir,

I thought that I should explain it. Further, the same newspaper is carrying another news with regard to an assault on a particular political party, which I will not talk about. They have already named the party and the Member, but I am still looking for more information.

Sir, it is very important to state at this juncture that local government authorities including the Colombo Municipal Council have been clearly and decisively being won by the National People's Power, the Government. Again, people have given the Government a chance to carry out their mandate and that step is being taken now.

Sir, we need an Opposition. Why? To criticize the wrong decisions of the Government and to give a good input as an Opposition. We fully welcome that, but quite unfortunately, what do we see in this Parliament? This Opposition is not being responsible except for a few Members on very rare occasions. We have a shouting match, a deliberately prepared shouting match for a morning session. Thereafter, none of them are in Parliament. Now, only a few are here and I can count them; it is only a few. But, at the start in the morning, it was full with the Opposition MPs. Their intention in the morning is to come and make sensational remarks, which are baseless, and get a voice clip out on their YouTube channels and Facebook pages. This is not how a responsible Opposition should act. I respect those few Opposition Members who are still seated here participating in this Debate; others are not here. Sir, I can count them. Out of the 59, there are only seven Opposition Members now. This is how they act. - [Interruption] No, we have more than that. Hon. Member, you are in the House. So, I am not attacking you in anyway. Therefore, Sir, my request is that this House should be a place for proper Debate, extending courtesies.

Now, let me come to the Orders that are being discussed today. The Hon. Minister is there. I would like to bring up a few important matters. I have been watching the Hon. Ministers speech on TV; though I went out to the washroom, I was watching his speech on TV. There are a few serious issues.

Whereupon THE HON. DEPUTY CHAIRPERSON OF COMMITTEES left the Chair, and THE HON. SANJEEWA RANASINGHA took the Chair.

( ) (The Hon. Faiszer Musthapha, PC) Hon. Presiding Member, I am thankful that I am given the opportunity to speak in relation to the Orders under the Reciprocal Recognition, Registration and Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act. Prior to this law, there was an Ordinance in the 1920s. With the repeal of that law, this Act came into being and under it, I believe, judgments of 53 countries would be allowed to be enforced here. The Hon. Minister of Justice and National Integration as well as the Hon. Minister of Women and Child Affairs are here in this House at this moment.

We know that with regard to divorce, there is a major problem of recognition of foreign judgments. I think this clears the path with regard to recognition of divorce proceedings in those 53 countries and thereby, the enforcement of foreign judgments.
Sir, I would also like to make an appeal to the Hon. Minister of Justice and National Integration and the Hon. Minister of Women and Child Affairs regarding this.
, with these Orders, I am sure this problem would be solved.

Sir, I would also like to emphasize another very important matter to this House. We have a proud judicial system. Parliament exercises its judicial powers through courts. So, we have a fundamental duty to protect our judges. Recently, the Kaduwela Magistrate was suspended because, unfortunately, there was a sex tape about her. That is not only an indictment against her, but against the system because it was a false and malicious statement. At various times, you could also see judges being attacked on social media. So, I appeal to the Hon. Minister of Justice to form a Select Committee and also this Government to take steps against persons who attack judges on social media. Unfortunately, today, such attacks against persons and judges take place not only in our jurisdiction, but also outside our jurisdiction. Therefore, if we are going to protect the integrity of our judicial system, we have to protect our judges from those malicious slander and defamatory statements.

In addition, Sir, there is another issue with regard to the Contempt of a Court, Tribunal or Institution Act in our country. We saw that a lawyer was locked up recently and the Bar Association of Sri Lanka had to intervene and seek his release. We also saw that a person was locked up because his phone rang in the court, which resulted in his death. The Bar Association of Sri Lanka has also expressed their concerns with regard to that. The lawyers too, in certain instances, find the Contempt of a Court, Tribunal or Institution Act an intimidation on the system; it intimidates them. Therefore, I appeal to this Government to revisit the Contempt of a Court, Tribunal or Institution Act and also to look at the report the Bar Association of Sri Lanka is preparing now. If you look at it, you would see that there are various reforms needed to the Act.

Sir, if you take our judicial system, there are only three career Judges in the Supreme Court today. So, we need to look at things differently and I believe that the NPP Government pledged to this country to look at things differently, that they will look at these issues in a holistic manner and at the concerns expressed by all quarters, in a positive manner.
In addition, Sir, our life expectancy is 75 years today.

Therefore, if you take our Judiciary, we need to increase the retirement age of the Judges of the Supreme Court and the Court of Appeal and also of the employees of the Public Service because when they are in their 60s, they are in their prime and it is sad to take them out of the system, which prevents them from contributing more towards the judicial system of this country. Therefore, we have to look at things differently.

Then, the question of law's delays. The law's delays in this country have been an issue for a long period of time. And, I, as a practising lawyer, would say that infrastructure - buildings and facilities - is not the only issue, but, today, clerical staff, stenographers, computers, photocopies, all these have also become an issue. Therefore, if we are to improve and have an expeditious justice system, we need to improve the facilities in the judicial system. At the moment, if you take courts, there is a greater shortage in staff required. Therefore, I would appeal to the Minister of Justice and National Integration to look at this matter and address it expeditiously.

Sir, we have a lot of laws to protect women in this country. Unfortunately, in Sri Lanka, domestic violence is on the rise. So, I appeal to the Minister, who is here, to educate the police and have a mechanism with regard to domestic violence.

There is another fundamental issue which I would like to bring to the notice of the House. The law of Sri Lanka is based on the presumption of innocence; until you are convicted, you are presumed innocent. , The ratio of toilets to our prisoners is low. Also, they do not have the liberty of having a pillow and a mat. Especially, at remand prisoners, the prison officials should look as persons against whom investigations are pending. Also, those officials should be taught that the presumption of innocence is operated in favour of the prisoners and therefore, they should not be treated as convicts.
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Sunil Watagala, Attorney-at-Law - Deputy Minister of Public Security and Parliamentary Affairs) , . , , . , . ,

Parliament adjourned accordingly at 3.36 p.m. until 9.30 a.m. on Thursday, 19th June, 2025.
